111.content:
You gaze down with interest at the still unopened package, deft fingers playing over its surface, careful not to snag a talon in its wrapping. It's not a small bundle by any means; then again, with your uncle's vaunted stature, that doesn't mean a whole lot. He remains one of the few dragons to retain a trace of the impressive size and bearing that will ensure the eternal status of draconity in the most cherished tales and legends, human and otherwise... And so what might seem a large accessory or object to another would be for him only just this side of too minuscule to be used.

...But enough about him. You have a present to savor.

It would be easy enough to tear free the wrappings and feast your eyes on the contents... but why be impatient? Leave the breakneck hastiness to the humans. Turning, you sit down in the large, impressive, and exquisitely comfortable chair just to the side of your dresser, well-worn from years of bearing your own similarly impressive frame in times of thought or contemplation. Much like the rest of your possessions and furnishings, it has an elegance, a style, more and more difficult to come across...

well, outside of a dragon's lair, at least. Even among beings so long-lived, some things will never change, and for you that includes a deep commitment to luxury and comfort in the interior of your home... and dignity, as well. On those few occasions when you must suffer human company to enter on business of whatever fashion, they are always suitably impressed and humbled. The dragons of yore may have rested upon heaps and piles of coinage, but with a more human-like body- well, discounting your tremendous advantage of size, of course- comes an ability to appreciate finer and admittedly more pleasant accomodations.

Whether they ever make it back into the world outside, after being so impressed and humbled? That's another matter entirely.

Grinning, a light and rumbling purr escaping your handsomely-scaled throat, you wonder, at your own size, whether you truly even need such a device as your uncle possessed. Certainly the possibilities of what you could do with such an ability are endless... but at the same time, there are others among your kin not so blessed with size as yourself who could probably use it much, much more.

That being considered... Probably not the secret of his shrinking ability, tantalizing as the possibility is. But what, then? Having savored the mystery for long enough, you slide your fingers into the wrapping's edge and start to work it loose...

12.content:
Kathy decided it was time to get away from the rat race. She had been working as a commodies broker for five years now and the pressure and stress were intensive. As a child growing up her parents had often taken her on camping trips and that is what she needed now. A trip to the woods, away from ringing phones, beeping computers, and men in general.
She packed lightly, she would only be gone for a week and since she would be backpacking into the woods she did not carry anything that she absolutely did not need.
She drove into the state forrest and when she ran out of road she parked her truck and placed the huge back pack on her back and began to hike into the thick forest.
Within an hour she was deep enough into the woods that she began to appreciate the quiet. She could hear the birds and occassionally a gentle breeze would wash over her and cool her down.
She had been hiking for about two hours when she came to a stream and she decided to take a break.
She removed her backpack and sat down. She reached into a side-zippered pocket on the backpack and retrieved a Three muskateers bar. The milk chocolate tasted good on her lips. While she was eating she surveyed the stream. It looked shallow enough to walk across, so she did. Once on the other side she began walking towards a large rock formation. The trail began to veer away from the rock formation so she stepped off of the trail and continued toward the rocks. Then suddenly the woods opened up into a small meadow. A small heard of deer were grazing at the other end of the meadow. She paused, then sat on a nearby rock and watched them graze, never removing her pack. They did not seem to notice her presence. Kathy listened. She knew she was completely alone. It was shady where she sat and she removed her pack and kind of eased down to the ground and used the rock to rest her back against.
And while she was watching the deer graze she dozed off.

Kathy awoke about an hour later with a start. The deer were gone and there was a new sound, one she did not recognize, but it sounded near-by. It sounded like a snoring sound. But not a human. Maybe it was a bear. She had never heard a bear snore, had not even come face to face with a wild bear and she did not want to now. She listened hard but the snoring seemed to be getting further away.
'Good'she thought. I certainly don't want to meet any bears. But just in case she got her pepper spray out of the back pack and got up and continued to hike towards the rock formation that loomed in the distance before her. As she got closer she noticed what appearred to be a cave entrance. It was about fifteen feet high by twenty or twenty-five feet wide. She wondered if there were any bears in the cave. As she neared the entrance to the cave she heard heavy breathing. She stopped in her tracks, there was no way she was going into the cave to find out what that breathing belonged to.
Now the sun was beginning to go down. She decided to back track to the last stream she had crossed. That would be a good place to make camp.
And hopefully it would far enough away from whatever creature or creatures that were in the cave.
Back at the stream Kathy removed her backpack, unpacked her one person tent, set it up in less than three minutes and then rolled her sleeping bag into the tent. Then she walked around her camp site picking up twigs and scraps of wood to start a small fire. Within a half an hour it had really gotten dark. Her fire was going and she had placed a coleman lantern on a rock near the entrance to her camp. She was just finishing her light supper which consisted of two hot dogs roasted over her fire. She reached into her back pack and retrieved a cold beer from the small ice chest. The beer was still cold and she knew it would be the last cold beer she would be able to enjoy. As she sipped her beer she lit her first cigarette of the day. Back at the office she was a pack a day smoker, but out here in the woods she had barely missed her smokes. But now with the beer the cigarette tasted good. As she finished smoking she suddenly realized how tired she was. She removed all of her clothes and slipped into her sleeping bag inside the tent. She was asleep almost instantly.

A pair of huge red eyes glowed in the distance.
They were about eighteen feet in the air and belonged to Earnest the Dragon. The sight of the young woman excited the dragon. He had not seen a human being in these woods in over five years. In fact, the last human he saw was a hunter and Earnest had eaten him. Not because he found humans to be that tasty but he thought he had better eat the man before the man decided to shoot him. Earnest did not like guns. It fact, guns were the only thing he feared. But the nude young
woman crawling into her tent excited Earnest and remined him of the days ehn he was a young dragon ---when Kings ruled the woods.

13521.content:
As the sun nears the top of the sky, Perciax awakens with a yawn.

"Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahmng... A wonderful sleep," he says lazily as he uncurls his body and rises from his bed of large, furry hides and piled woolen blankets. He wasn't a large drake; "only" thirty feet long, from head to tail-tip, "only" standing fifteen high, and "only" weighing eight tons (mostly muscle, naturally)... But, of course, he was more than large enough, and more than strong enough, to enforce his dominion over the Greatwoods, the largest and most bountiful forest in the land. Making sure he was the only dragon anywhere for miles, he exercised complete control and ownership of everything under the forest canopy: Every river full of fish, every wild orchard of apples and peaches, every thicket of blackberries... And any and all of the creatures that called the woods home, as well as any who dared step foot within. He ensured that the woods would always be bountiful, full of life... And therefore full of food.

His den, cozily located inside of a mountain cave, is lavishly decorated with a variety of statues, tapestries and rugs that he managed to "convince" a number of trading caravans to part with. In various nooks, crannies and antechambers within his den, he's put a great many things that catch his interest, many of which he'd also "liberated" from caravans.

One antechamber held massive piles of golden ingots, silver coins, sparkling jewels and a number of other baubles and treasures. He took great pride in this collection, as all dragons would, often spending hours just staring at his horde.

In a nook by his bed, he'd amassed a collection of weapons: Daggers, swords, axes, spears, hammers... A veritable arsenal of gleaming arms, all lining the walls. As a strong, fire-breathing drake, he didn't have much use for them... But as a bit of a sadist, they were a veritable toy-chest to be used on whatever live "playthings" he'd bring home. And for the playthings he was done with...

... He had two antechambers for those, one for each of his favorite hobbies: A chamber for butchery and curing, where he'd slice apart his prey, salt it and hang the various cuts of meat around to preserve and smoke them. And for the prey of a more "furry" persuasion, he had a primitive tannery, where'd he skin his prey and process the hides; most of his "bedding" came from that very antechamber.

Right now, he hadn't had the inclination to peruse any of these, however; he'd just gotten up, and right now, it was breakfast time. He walked out of his den to take in all of his domain; the towering oaks, the chirping birds, all of the shrubs, the glutted animals... All were his. To his left was a tiny basin, only eighty feet from wall to wall with the floor covered in long grass and plentiful berries and fallen acorns; this was his "ranch," another hobby of his.

Milling about the basin were a number of sheep, cattle and swine, all fat and gorged, packed together as they went about their business. He'd toss in whatever vegetation he'd feel like providing them, they'd eat, and get fatter... And every so often, he'd pull one out and take his "compensation" for his work. Today, he reached into the basin, sending the animals into a panic, and pulled out a fat sow. He looked the pink, squealing blob over, hefted it in his claw... It seemed to be about three-quarters of a ton. Not the largest he'd ever "raised," but still not bad. He lifted its heaving, quivering gut up to his waiting maw and took a bite out of the hog as if it were a piece of fruit. It squealed in agony as Perciax ate and eventually fell silent as it either passed out or died of shock. With a few more bites, he'd finished his pig, licking his lips of the fat and blood that stained them.

"My, that was exquisite..." he said languidly. As much as he'd enjoyed his meal, it was not nearly enough to sate his hunger... It was only a snack, as the livestock always were, or something he'd eat when he (rarely) failed to find anything else. His taste was more for something to hunt... So, hunting is what he'd do, today.

But, where to go? He could go anywhere and find himself a meal... Even if it didn't matter much, he still needed to choose.
13521.title: Lord Perciax of the Greatwoods

135211.content:
Perciax decided he'd make his way down to one of the forest's many, many "wild" fruit orchards that he'd cultivated over the years. He'd planted so many different kinds of fruit trees and raised them with care, to ensure that he'd grow the best and largest fruit around... Not because he had any particular love of apples and peaches and whatnot, though.

While he did enjoy a little taste of this and that, what the orchards were really there for were the various denizens of the forest. This, of course, was not for any altruistic reason. The green drake could care less that he'd given the Greatwoods the best-tasting pears or the largest plums in the land.

What he did care for, however, was the size of his prey. The various creatures of Perciax's domain, both feral and anthropomorphic, absolutely adored the green drake's "offering" of fruits. They'd gorge themselves on them, for hours and sometimes days on end, becoming much, much fatter through their over-consumption of this fruit that near-instantly metabolized within them. Oftentimes, when Perciax came down to one of his orchards, he'd find one of the creatures with their faces buried in a pile of fruit or berries, eating away like the swine he kept, and completely oblivious to the drake's approach. or simply lying on their backs, too fat and lazy to get up and leave. All Perciax needed to do was stroll on over and pick them up, much like over-ripe fruit themselves, which he'd either drag back to his lair or simply nibble upon right then and there. He'd always make sure that some of the fat from his various meals made its way back to the orchards to fertilize the trees and bushes and keep them bountiful, of course.

He'd collected many a "plaything" from these, providing him hours of play and an abundance of meat, not to mention an enormous hide to add to his bed. And the ones that Perciax didn't collect? They'd simply be picked off by the predators of the Greatwoods, adding on to their bulk, providing the drake with other fattened prey. The fruit trees completely enriched the woods, both directly and indirectly: Those creatures who did not feed from the trees were fed from themselves, and the insects that the trees brought fed the fish who in turn would feed many of the predators. It was a glorious food-chain that Perciax had set up... And the green drake himself sat atop that chain, far above all other creatures.

And today, the dragon would exercise his position. Whatever fur or animal he found picking berries, he'd simply pick them, snapping them up on the spot or tossing them into the large cart he dragged along with him on these trips; as a wingless dragon, he didn't have many options when it came to transporting whatever he caught.

And so, Perciax hitched himself up to his cart and make his way down to a peach orchard. It wasn't long before he'd started to find some prey. The first he'd found was a plump feral deer, about the size of a cow, nibbling a half-eaten head-sized peach off of the ground; this one went straight into the drake's maw, crying out as it was torn apart by Perciax's many sharp teeth and swallowed down.

The next he'd found was a rather rotund lynx-girl, lying against one of the trees and lazily gnawing on a peach, chasing each bite down with a handful of blackberries and dribbling juice down her quivering flesh-pumpkins and lovely, large round gut. The green drake simply picked her up by her jiggling belly, holding her in his jaw. He suckled off the juices staining her body as she kicked and screamed. When he was done, he simply jammed a large peach into the lynx's mouth, effectively gagging her, and tossed her into the cart.

A few more victims later, he'd made his way to something that he found quite interesting...
135211.title: A Dragon Among Apples

14.content:
Out on the plains of Haran, he stood out amongst the growing herd of dragons, his eyes taking in all he could. He would try to remember every moment, every detail to bring back to his friends in Juret. Good lord, but they were big! How magnificent they looked against the backdrop of never ending grass.

One of the dragons, a smaller dark red one, with iridescent scales covering her back, turned to him and lowered her head so that her right eye was level with him. The secondary scales covering over her eyelid were a brilliant orange, shining in the morning light like jewels.

"You, human, are truly blessed today aren't you? For you see the gathering of the Dragon worlds, readying ourselves for the annual migration to the caves. Truly a sight that not many of your kind has witnessed from the ground!"

He nodded slowly, afraid to show too much excitement or ignorance of what he was seeing. His presence here was tolerated by the dragons, not welcomed. Dragons were a solitary sort, and also very independent. They needed no other race to depend on for anything. They were the kings of their realm.

He thought for a moment that the proper thing to do would be to show reverance to the small female. He toyed with how this should be done, a bow perhaps? a Nod of deference? The female cocked her head slightly to one side as she watched him contemplate this newfound idea.

"For sure human, your knowledge of us is limited. However, I appreciate just the mere fact you wish to show respect towards us in some manner."

The man looked up, startled that the dragon knew what he was thinking.

"How do you know this?" He asked quietly, looking up into her liquid eye, watching the fire swirl in the pupil, entranced by the simple beauty.

The dragon smiled, in the way that dragons do, winked her eye, and turned away. "You will learn much about us in the months to come human. Learn and understand us, and then you will know."

The village of Delmora had lived in a quaint harmony for many generation. People lived out quiet, happy, if uneventful lives.

That is, until several years ago, when the dragon first came to the village, threatening to destroy it unless the town sacrificed one of its own. Being the vicious, domineering, sex-crazed green beast that it was, it had a particular taste for young virgin girls, where he would either devour them on the spot or whisk them away to his mountainous lair where they were never seen again.

The dragon also had a fond taste for young men as well, whether to satisfy its sick desires or to remind the people that whether you were male or female, no one was safe.

You, the protagonist, or rather the dragon's next likely victim, are...
